I realize that people run against each other one week, then buddy up the next week. Kerry had to criticize his oponents while running against them. Edwards, from what I understand, doesn't like to go negative so much, but the two are now running mates, and this makes sense since Edwards was second in popularity during the primaries (after Dean? forgot about him.) 
 
 If in 2000, McCain were to have run with Bush as his VP, then it all would have made sense. But, McCain made it a point NOT to run as VP under Bush. 
 
 Something tells me that McCain decided that it would be most prudent to show solidarity within the Republican Party. If he didn't endorse Bush (begrudgingly) it would look as if there was division within the party, which doesn't look good to voters. It may just be a matter of loyalty to the party trumping personal issues.
